but nine times out of ten, it's nobody else around.
translation.ko: 하지만 열에 아홉은 주변에 아무도 없어요

translation.en: You know the rules. We hike together--
translation.ko: 다들 규칙 알지? 우린 같이 걷고…

translation.en: -[boy] We don't need them to eat. -We eat together. Yes, that's the rules.
translation.ko: - 먹을 건 안 줘도 돼요? - 같이 먹고, 그래, 그게 규칙이야

translation.en: He was able to attract some of the most affluent families in American history.
translation.ko: 카티사노의 고객 중에는 미국 역사상 가장 부유한 가문인 록펠러가도 있었고

translation.en: The Rockefellers.
translation.ko: 미국 역사상 가장 부유한 가문인 록펠러가도 있었고

translation.en: The grandson of the late governor of Arkansas, they sent him there.
translation.ko: 고인이 된 아칸소주 주지사도 손자를 거기에 보냈어요

translation.en: All believing that this was a legitimate, credible program
translation.ko: 다들 이게 합법적이고 믿을 만한 프로그램이라 믿었죠

translation.en: that helped kids get centered,
they came back respectful and as good as new.
translation.ko: 새로운 모습으로 의젓하게 돌아올 거라 믿었어요

translation.en: We just had to deal with it in a very straightforward and controlled fashion.
translation.ko: 이런 일은 직접적이고 통제된 방식으로 대처해야 해요

translation.en: It's almost something we had to go through.
And it turned out all right. We ended up becoming very close.
translation.ko: 어쨌든 다 잘됐고 아주 많이 가까워졌어요

translation.en: I was seeing a doctor, and he brought it up to my…
translation.ko: 병원에 갔는데 의사 선생님이 아마 엄마한테 그 얘기를 하셨을 거예요

translation.en: I think it was my mom.
translation.ko: 의사 선생님이 아마 엄마한테 그 얘기를 하셨을 거예요

translation.en: And we ended up getting the Health Care America video.
translation.ko: 그렇게 헬스 케어 아메리카 영상을 보게 됐죠

translation.en: [Steve] What do you think you really wanna do?
I don't know. I just want some freedom or something.
[Steve] The key to therapy with a young person is relationship,
and unless they have that relationship…
[man] The movie itself was very persuasive.
[Steve] …achieve all that they might otherwise.
[man] During his teenage years, Adam was just totally out of control.
translation.ko: 애덤은 10대 때 통제 불능이었어요 "애덤 - 18세, 1993년 5월 헬스 케어 아메리카 입소"

translation.en: He couldn't stand dealing with his mother.
I think a couple of times, he threw some knives at her. I remember that.
translation.ko: 실제로 자기 엄마한테 두어 번 칼을 던진 게 기억나요

translation.en: [Adam] I was an angry kid,
and I think I used being adopted as an excuse to be that way.
translation.ko: 입양을 핑계 삼아 그랬던 것 같아요

translation.en: We were basically desperate and had to do something.
All of you, I think, know why you're here.
translation.ko: 다들 여기 왜 왔는지 알 거야

translation.en: You haven't been taking responsibility for your own actions.
Now it's time that you learn that.
I needed some kind of guidance in my life, 'cause I really had none.
translation.ko: 삶의 지침 같은 게 필요했어요 그런 게 전혀 없었거든요

translation.en: My dad worked all the time.
[Adam] So I flew into Saint Thomas.
I was ready for something different.
I was ready to be better, to work on myself.
translation.ko: 더 나아지고 노력할 준비가 돼 있었죠

translation.en: For the next six and a half months, the program was definitely a game changer.
translation.ko: 그 후 6개월 반 동안 그 프로그램은 완전히 판을 뒤집었어요

translation.en: It pretty much changed everything.
[Larry] First time I actually met Steve was when I went to Costa Rica.
translation.ko: "래리 - 애덤의 아버지" 코스타리카에 갔을 때 스티브를 처음 만났어요

translation.en: Adam, he'd been down there a while.
translation.ko: 애덤은 거기 있은 지 꽤 됐고 그동안 못 봤죠

translation.en: We hadn't seen him, and they thought it may be good to come visit him.
translation.ko: 애덤은 거기 있은 지 꽤 됐고 그동안 못 봤죠 캠프에서 한번 보러 오라고 했어요

translation.en: [Steve] What would you say to your dad if he were here right now?
translation.ko: 지금 여기에 아빠가 계신다면 뭐라고 하고 싶어?

translation.en: [Adam] I'd give him a big hug.
-[Steve] Better turn around. -[Larry] Turn around. I'm here.
translation.ko: - 뒤돌아 봐 - 돌아 봐, 아빠 왔어

translation.en: I mean, it's very emotional.
I'm… I'm not a real emotional person, but that… that really got my emotions.
translation.ko: 별로 감정적인 사람이 아닌데도 정말 울컥했어요

translation.en: Thought I'd come for a visit.
[Nadine] Most people I talk to who've been through these experiences…
[Nadine] …you can't talk about it where you're not re-traumatized by it
translation.ko: 그 일을 얘기할 때마다 그때의 충격을 다시 느낄 수밖에 없어요

translation.en: for at least five years.
Yeah, you might be a spoiled kid complaining, but nobody cares.
translation.ko: 네, 버릇없고 불만 많은 애한테 누가 관심이나 있겠어요?

translation.en: If your own parent doesn't care about you,
translation.ko: 그 아이의 부모가 관심을 갖지 않으면

translation.en: nobody cares.
Like, who sends their kid to something like that?
translation.ko: 대체 어떤 부모가 자기 자식을 그런 데 보내요?

translation.en: I mean, my parents came to pick me up,
and my mother didn't wanna get close to me 'cause I smelled.
translation.ko: 엄마는 저한테 냄새가 나서 가까이 오지 않으려 하셨어요

translation.en: We got in the car. She rolled the window down, like, "Oh, she stinks."
translation.ko: 차에 타서는 창문을 내리고 말했죠 '냄새가 지독해'

translation.en: You know, it was just like, "What the fuck?" Like, "What is wrong with you people?"
translation.ko: 전 너무 어이가 없었어요 어떻게 그럴 수 있냐며 소리쳤죠

translation.en: [Larry] I'll never forget when you graduated from that program.
translation.ko: 네가 그 프로그램 수료했을 때를 절대 못 잊을 거야

translation.en: You had been clean for a period of time.
Yeah.
Got back to Atlanta, and it just, you know…
You know, it took about a week before it started all over.
No, I… I think it was about a month, and then I… I went back to my old ways.
translation.ko: 한 달은 버텼을 거예요 그러고 다시 옛날로 돌아갔죠

translation.en: Yeah, so not a lot changed.
Quite frankly, I probably should have left you there for the rest of your life.
translation.ko: 솔직히 널 평생 거기에 뒀어야 해

translation.en: It was, you know--
-For the rest of my life? -[Larry] Yes, in the jungles.
[Chris] My first lead was hearing from a research station
translation.ko: 제가 처음 잡은 단서는 세인트존섬에 있는 연구소 직원들의 제보였어요

translation.en: on the island of Saint John.
What they told me is that a bunch of kids and a few adults came up on a boat
translation.ko: 한 무리의 아이들과 어른 몇 명이 배를 타고 왔는데

translation.en: and had told them they were there to do some training
translation.ko: 섬사람들에게 자신들은 헬스 케어 아메리카라는 단체고

translation.en: for an organization called Health Care America.
translation.ko: 섬사람들에게 자신들은 헬스 케어 아메리카라는 단체고 훈련하러 왔다고 했대요

translation.en: But then they started noticing that the kids were very disheveled,
translation.ko: 근데 아이들의 모습이 무척 초췌하고 후줄근하더래요

translation.en: and there didn't seem to be any structure there.
So the head of the research station there
called the US Virgin Islands bureau of business licensing,
translation.ko: 미국 버진아일랜드 사업 허가국에 연락해 봤는데

translation.en: and there was no such thing as Health Care America
licensed to do business in the US Virgin Islands.
This was a completely covert operation. There were no permits issued.
translation.ko: 완전한 비밀 작전이었어요 어떤 허가도 받지 않았고

translation.en: There was no law enforcement acknowledgment.
There was no public health inspections going on.
They just kinda came in, out of the blue,
dropped anchor, and started doing "wilderness therapy" in the tropics.
translation.ko: 닻을 내리고 열대 지역에서 '야생 치료'를 시작한 거예요

translation.en: [Chris] And so, as the authorities start closing in,
Cartisano decides it's time to make an exit.
[Chris] The captain sails from Saint John to another island
translation.ko: 선장은 세인트존을 떠나 다른 섬으로 갑니다

translation.en: that's pretty much almost uninhabited.
These kids, they don't really know what's going on.
translation.ko: 아이들은 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지 몰라요

translation.en: They truly are like these prisoners on this floating therapy camp
translation.ko: 이 아이들은 치료라고는 없는 떠다니는 치료 캠프의

translation.en: that has zero therapy.
And they're out there in the ocean for months at a time.
translation.ko: 한 번에 몇 달씩 그냥 바다 위에 떠 있는 거예요

translation.en: Hi, Dad. We love you.
It won't be the same at Christmastime without you here.
translation.ko: 당신 없는 크리스마스 연휴는 예전 같지 않을 거야

translation.en: We miss you very much.
-[kid] Bye, Dad! -Bye! Bye!
[Ashley] I was in Health Care America for nine months.
We never had any idea where we were going
or how long we were going to be there or what the plan was.
translation.ko: 우린 어디로 가서 얼마나 있을지 계획이 뭔지 전혀 몰랐죠

translation.en: And it seemed like we were always trying to get somewhere
just going from island to island to island
and, you know, just staying long enough to get essentials.
translation.ko: 섬에서 섬으로 계속 옮겨 다녔고 섬에는 생필품을 구할 수 있을 만큼만 머물렀어요

translation.en: We went from the Virgin Islands to Puerto Rico, Mona Island,
Dominican Republic,
Haiti, and then we went to Jamaica.
And then we went to Venezuela and Cartagena, Colombia.
translation.ko: 그리고 거기서 베네수엘라와 콜롬비아의 카르타헤나로 갔죠

translation.en: [Chris] These are not places that are close together.
They're literally all over the Caribbean.
[Ashley] I was just scared of what was going to happen.
I just… It's really hard to explain.
Never knowing when you're going home. Um…
Just feeling it was going on forever.
Just feeling like you're never going to be good enough to go home.
translation.ko: 집에 갈 수 있는 착한 어린이는 영영 될 수 없을 것 같죠

translation.en: [Chris] I end up finding out that the program is down to just five kids
translation.ko: 전 마침내 그 프로그램에 5명만 남았다는 걸 알게 됐어요

translation.en: on a catamaran.
And after several weeks, they're within landfall of Puerto Rico.
translation.ko: 몇 주 후에 그들은 푸에르토리코 육지 근처에 도착했어요

translation.en: Several of the kids decide, "We gotta get out of this."
translation.ko: 몇몇 아이는 결심했죠 '우리 여기서 나가야 해'

translation.en: They were trying to find somebody to believe them, to talk to,
translation.ko: 그 아이들은 믿고 말할 사람을 찾았어요

translation.en: like, "Hey, we just escaped. Help us!"
The captain is so tired of these kids escaping
translation.ko: 선장은 아이들이 도망치는 데 너무 지쳤어요

translation.en: that he decides, "I'm gonna tie these kids up in a car,
translation.ko: 그래서 아이들을 차에 묶어 두기로 하죠

translation.en: put nooses around their neck,
and tie the rope to the car so the kids don't get away."
The Puerto Rican authorities come swooping in,
thinking that it's some sort of, like, organized crime, you know, hit.
translation.ko: 조직범죄 같은 건 줄 알고 현장을 덮친 거죠

translation.en: The kids went back home and started telling their parents,
translation.ko: 아이들은 집에 돌아가 부모에게 말하기 시작했어요

translation.en: "Do you know what you just sent me to?"
The authorities get involved, the Puerto Rican Public Health.
Bottom line, no permit, no authorization to do what they're doing,
translation.ko: 결론은, 허가를 받지 않았어요 그런 일을 할 권리가 없었죠

translation.en: and Cartisano has done his usual "tough love 'em and leave 'em."
translation.ko: 카티사노는 늘 하던 대로 거친 사랑을 주고 떠났죠

translation.en: Nowhere in the picture.
So from a reporting standpoint, everybody thinks he's gonna go dark.
translation.ko: 보도의 관점에서 보면 다들 스티브가 종적을 감추고 다른 직업을 찾겠거니 했어요

translation.en: He's gonna find another vocation.
translation.ko: 다들 스티브가 종적을 감추고 다른 직업을 찾겠거니 했어요

translation.en: [Debbie] We'd lost everything.
Money that was coming to him for the program that he was using for the program,
translation.ko: 그 프로그램을 통해 들어오고 사용된 돈은

translation.en: you know, I don't recall seeing any of it.
translation.ko: 전 한 푼도 구경 못 했어요

translation.en: I knew that things were getting pretty bad financially.
translation.ko: 집안 형편이 안 좋아지고 있다는 건 알았어요

translation.en: Um, you know, "We can't buy that. We can't do this. We can't do that."
translation.ko: "케이티 - 스티브와 데비의 딸" '저건 못 사 이건 못 해, 저건 안 돼'

translation.en: And at the time, I didn't understand as much.
Yeah, we… we… we had nothing.
My dad was brilliant.
He's literally the smartest person I've ever met.
translation.ko: 제가 만난 사람 중에 제일 똑똑한 분이었죠

translation.en: Um, he could've done so many things.
So I was just like, "Dad, please, like, do something different."
translation.ko: 그래서 전 이랬죠 '아빠, 제발 다른 걸 해요'

translation.en: I was angry at him because I wanted him to do something else
translation.ko: 아빠한테 화가 났어요 아빠가 다른 일을 했으면 했거든요

translation.en: so we could have a normal life.
I just wanted our family to be normal.
[Debbie] That's real good.
Yeah. Hi.
-Hi. -Hi.
[Debbie] Can you look at the dinosaur for me up there?
Yeah, that's good.
[Debbie] When David was in second grade, he was shy.
[Debbie] Can you turn around and face the wall? Over here.
[Debbie] But then, when he turned 12, he started hanging out
translation.ko: 그런데 12살이 됐을 때 술, 마리화나, 파티를 즐기는 애들과 어울리기 시작했어요

translation.en: with kids that liked to drink and party and smoke marijuana and stuff,
translation.ko: 술, 마리화나, 파티를 즐기는 애들과 어울리기 시작했어요

translation.en: and he quickly… I think he discovered that his shyness would go away.
translation.ko: 약을 하면 수줍음이 사라진다는 걸 알게 됐나 봐요

translation.en: [Catie] He started using really, really heavily. Um…
He didn't have, like, a stopping…
There was… There was no threshold for Dave, right?
Like, he wanted to do as much as he could all the time, no matter what.
translation.ko: 약이란 약은 그냥 닥치는 대로 먹었죠

translation.en: [Debbie] It just spiraled down. He got heavily into drugs.
translation.ko: 그냥 무너져 내렸어요 약에 너무 빠져버렸죠

translation.en: Oh, it was really hard. I was working full-time.
Uh, Steve was doing odd jobs here and there.
[Chris] Steve Cartisano was still convinced
that wilderness therapy was a good business.
translation.ko: 야생 치료가 좋은 사업이라고 굳게 믿었어요

translation.en: So Steve connects with some of these businessmen
translation.ko: 그래서 스티브는 이 프로그램을 하고 싶어 하는

translation.en: who want to start a program in Samoa.
translation.ko: 그래서 스티브는 이 프로그램을 하고 싶어 하는 사모아 사업가 몇을 찾았죠

translation.en: Steve has become a consultant.
However, the legacy of Steve Cartisano was catching up with Steve Cartisano,
translation.ko: 하지만 스티브 카티사노는 이미 엮인 게 많잖아요

translation.en: so he would introduce himself to parents as Steve Michaels.
translation.ko: 그래서 부모들에게 자신을 스티브 마이클스로 소개하죠 "스티브 마이클스는 스티브 카티사노다"

translation.en: Steve was able to get the program in Samoa up and going.
So we made the determination that we needed to send David.
So we actually sent two men down there to kidnap him,
just like we had other students, and we sent him to Samoa.
translation.ko: 남자 2명이 와서 애를 납치해 사모아로 데려갔죠

translation.en: [man 1] What is this? This is the entrance?
translation.ko: "퍼시픽 코스트 아카데미 캠프 사모아" 뭐지, 여기가 입구인가?

translation.en: [man 2] This is the quote, unquote "guard."
Makes sure no people come in that aren't supposed to.
There's a big sign up there.
[man 1] That's right. That's the sign. "Pacific Coast Academy."
A far cry different than what the brochure would lead you to believe.
translation.ko: 안내 책자에 나온 거랑은 완전 다르다

translation.en: [man] It was sold to my mom in a brochure. It was a really nice, beautiful brochure.
translation.ko: 엄마는 안내 책자에 넘어갔어요 진짜 근사하고 아름다웠죠

translation.en: It looks like you're going on vacation.
It was about 25 to 30,000 dollars, depending on the kid.
[interviewer] How did your mom afford it?
Uh, she sold our house that we lived in, so pretty major transformation for us.
translation.ko: 우리가 살던 집을 파셨어요 우리 삶에 큰 변화가 일어났죠

translation.en: [interviewer] What were the other kids like?
[Kurt] Uh, I actually knew one of 'em when I was there. Amber.
She was, uh, somebody that I knew from Costa Mesa.
We had mutual friends together, and we were on good terms.
translation.ko: 같이 아는 친구가 있었고 사이도 좋았어요

translation.en: We looked at each other and were like, "Holy shit! How did this happen?"
translation.ko: 우린 서로 보고 깜짝 놀랐어요 '대박, 어떻게 이런 일이 있지?'

translation.en: "How did somebody that I knew from home end up here in Samoa of all places?"
translation.ko: '어떻게 고향에서 알던 사람을 이 사모아에서 만나?'

translation.en: I was happy. It was a relief.
[interviewer] Did you ever meet Steve Cartisano?
translation.ko: 스티브 카티사노를 만난 적 있어요? "앰버 - 14세, 2000년 3월 퍼시픽 코스트 아카데미 입소"

translation.en: Once.
He just made a pop-up to check on his kid,
which is strange
that he was sending his own kid to one of his camps.
translation.ko: 자기 캠프에 자기 아들을 보낸다는 게

translation.en: [Kurt] Steve Cartisano was like,
"You should help other kids by teaching them what you know,"
and I was like, "You mean like junior staff?"
translation.ko: 제가 주니어 스태프를 말하는 거냐고 묻자

translation.en: He's like, "Yeah." Everyone wants to be junior staff.
translation.ko: 그렇다고 했어요 모든 아이가 원하는 자리였죠

translation.en: You're at the top of it. You get better treatment, better food.
translation.ko: 아이들의 우두머리가 되고 대우나 음식도 훨씬 좋았거든요

translation.en: I'd be the one delegating what to do, and…
forcing people to do it if they didn't wanna do it.
translation.ko: 하기 싫다고 하면 강제로 시킬 수 있었어요

translation.en: This man was straight-up offering me an easier time. "Yeah, I'll… I'll do it."
translation.ko: 그 사람은 편한 생활을 제안했고 전 바로 하겠다고 했죠

translation.en: My dad was super, super hopeful.
Dave was doing really well.
My dad was working, and it was more consistent.
translation.ko: 아빠는 일을 하셨고 상황은 훨씬 안정적이었죠

translation.en: Things were really good, and then, of course, just like always, things went…
translation.ko: 그렇게 다 잘됐는데 아니나 다를까 사건이 터졌죠

translation.en: [Chris] I got contacted by an attorney who had a videotape
translation.ko: 한 변호사가 영상을 갖고 있다며 연락해 왔어요

translation.en: made by a father and a son who was in the program
translation.ko: 그 프로그램에 참여했던 아들과 아버지가 만든 영상이었고

translation.en: that they wanted me to see.
So I went and visited the attorney in her office.
They dim the lights, and the TV kinda flickers on,
and it's a really poor quality videotape,
but it was obvious it was shot in the jungle.
And I think my first impression was
it was like something you would maybe see for a Vietnamese POW camp.
translation.ko: 베트남 포로수용소에서나 볼 법한 장면이란 거였어요

translation.en: Oh, yeah, I spent a month and a half in isolation for being a bad influence.
translation.ko: 네, 전 나쁜 영향을 줬다는 이유로 한 달 반 동안 격리됐었어요

translation.en: They can't compare. I got the record.
translation.ko: 그건 명함도 못 내밀지 난 기록 세웠어요

translation.en: Three and a half months, baby. Three and a half months.
You couldn't even tell that they were kids. They were emaciated. They were dirty.
They were covered head to toe with insect bites.
translation.ko: 머리부터 발끝까지 벌레에 물린 상처로 덮여 있었어요

translation.en: No matter how bad I am, I don't deserve to get beat.
translation.ko: 내가 아무리 나쁜 놈이어도 그렇게 때리면 안 되죠

translation.en: Yes, me too.
They were really, literally, living like animals.
translation.ko: 정말 말 그대로 짐승처럼 살고 있었어요

translation.en: Um, I've been here about almost a year.
I've been hit about seven… I've been hit about seven times here.
-Mom, Dad, I wanna come home. Thank you. -[interviewer] You're 18?
translation.ko: 엄마, 아빠, 집에 가고 싶어요 고마워요 - 18살이에요? - 18살이에요

translation.en: I'm 18. It's Illegal for them to keep me here, but they refuse to let me go.
translation.ko: - 18살이에요? - 18살이에요 날 여기 가두는 건 불법이지만 안 보내 준대요

translation.en: This is my bed, and this is Brandon's bed.
translation.ko: 이건 제 침대고 이건 브랜든 침대예요

translation.en: This is rocks and a little bit of hay.
The place was nothing when I got there. It was a clearing in the jungle.
translation.ko: 거기에 갔는데 아무것도 없었어요 정글 속 공터였죠

translation.en: So the place was being built by the other kids.
So we were building roads. We were digging ditches to put in pipes.
translation.ko: 우린 도로를 깔고 파이프 넣을 도랑을 팠죠

translation.en: We were putting in the sewers.
We were putting everything, all the general infrastructure needed
translation.ko: 우린 필요한 기반 시설을 전부 다 만들었어요

translation.en: in order for it to become something that'll make the landowners money.
translation.ko: 그 땅 주인은 그냥 앉아서 돈 번 거죠

translation.en: It's a forced labor camp.
[interviewer] When you ran away, what happened?
They beat the crap out of us and made us stay up all night on our hands…
translation.ko: 두드려 패고 밤새 못 자게 해요

translation.en: Or on our knees with our hands above our head.
translation.ko: 밤새 무릎 꿇고 손을 머리 위에 올리고 있죠

translation.en: [Chris] The thing that struck me after seeing that video
was that this was the darkest chapter of the whole Cartisano saga that I remember.
translation.ko: 제가 아는 카티사노 이야기의 가장 어두운 챕터란 거였어요

translation.en: It was a much more sinister kinda feeling.
The abuse, the situation, the conditions… seemed a lot worse.
Hi. I'm Amber Michelle.
Um… Do you want them to know how long I've been here?
-[interviewer] Yeah. -I've been here for almost 16 months.
translation.ko: - 응 - 여기 온 지 거의 16개월 됐어요

translation.en: Uh, about… Around this time last year,
I was hog-tied,
slammed down, and…
Shit! Staff's listening. They're gonna come here right now.
translation.ko: 젠장, 직원들이 듣고 있어 이제 여기로 올 거야

translation.en: [interviewer] Don't worry.
[Amber] So we were cleaning tables.
I made it very clear that I was done.
And I was then called into the head guy of the camp at that particular time.
translation.ko: 근데 특정 시간에 캠프 책임자한테 불려 갔어요

translation.en: He told me I was going to iso, to isolation.
And I looked at him flat-out and said, "No, I'm not. That's not…"
translation.ko: 전 그 사람을 똑바로 보며 말했죠 '아뇨, 말도 안 돼요'

translation.en: I was like, "I've done nothing wrong. I'm not going."
So, all of a sudden, there was four of the students.
They flipped me over to where I was face down.
translation.ko: 그 애들은 제 몸을 돌려서 엎드리게 했죠

translation.en: Then they pulled my arms back and tied my arms.
They just decided to go ahead and tie 'em to my feet too.
They didn't have staff doing it because they knew it was child abuse,
translation.ko: 직원들이 안 했어요 그러면 아동 학대니까요

translation.en: so they had students do it.
[interviewer] When you say "they," who do you mean?
Kurt.
I remember tying her up to the pole in the hut.
I wasn't part of the initial hog-tie part.
I was with her for many hours, and her hands were turning purple and blue,
translation.ko: 앰버와 꽤 오래 같이 있었는데 앰버 손이 파랗게 변하더라고요

translation.en: so when it was my turn, I let her go, you know?
translation.ko: 그래서 제 차례가 되면 풀어 줬어요

translation.en: I released her a little bit, gave her a bit of motion in her hands,
translation.ko: 줄을 느슨하게 풀어서 손을 움직일 수 있게 해 줬죠

translation.en: and then it got nighttime, and not a lot of sleep.
So what are we supposed to do? And the staff said, "Throw water on her."
translation.ko: 직원에게 어떻게 하냐고 물었더니 얼굴에 물을 뿌리라고 했죠

translation.en: It started off with just little mugs of water.
Then it went to pitchers of water. Then it went to five gallons of water at one time.
translation.ko: 물 주전자가 됐어요 한 번에 물 20리터를 부었죠

translation.en: They wouldn't let me breathe when they were doing it.
translation.ko: 물을 부을 땐 숨도 못 쉬게 했어요

translation.en: I took no pleasure in that.
I don't want to do that to somebody, but we would not have done it
translation.ko: 저도 누구한테 그러고 싶지 않았어요 아주 높은 자리에 있는 직원이 시키지 않았다면

translation.en: without somebody of extremely high position in the staff
translation.ko: 아주 높은 자리에 있는 직원이 시키지 않았다면

translation.en: had instructed us to do it.
When she was tied up, I was explaining it to her.
translation.ko: 앰버가 묶여 있을 때 다 설명했어요

translation.en: I was like, "This place is full of shit. It's an absolute scam."
This should not happen anywhere, and she knew I wasn't in charge of that,
translation.ko: 어디서도 벌어져선 안 되는 일이고 앰버는 제가 원해서 그런 게 아닌 걸 알았어요

translation.en: so I don't think she personally held any negative feelings to me.
translation.ko: 앰버는 제가 원해서 그런 게 아닌 걸 알았어요 그래서 저한테 개인적인 감정은 없을 거예요

translation.en: [interviewer] How did you feel towards Kurt for doing that?
translation.ko: 그런 일을 한 커트에게 어떤 마음이 들었어요?

translation.en: Betrayed.
Like, how… How could you not tell them no?
After the two days that I was tied up, they took me to an isolation place
translation.ko: 절 이틀간 묶어둔 뒤에 격리하는 곳으로 데려갔어요

translation.en: called "The Vow."
It's on the other side of the island, and when I was there…
-[interviewer] Did you get beat there? -I was sexually abused there.
I already know that he doesn't wanna hear it, so…
Girls weren't ever sent to this village. I was the first one.
translation.ko: 여자들은 그 마을에 안 보냈어요 제가 처음이었죠

translation.en: So where they had us stay was, uh…
It was the chief of the village. Chief Tui.
One day, when all his family was gone at church and working,
translation.ko: 하루는 가족이 다 교회에 가거나 일하러 가고

translation.en: it was just me and him there,
and I didn't have to work 'cause it was Sunday.
And…
he started to sexually abuse me.
[Amber] I remember I was sitting.
He… started to…
Like, he had his hand on my back and on my arm, and then started to…
translation.ko: 제 등과 팔에 손을 갖다 대더니

translation.en: He started to f…
Fondling on me, and…
I…
I didn't know what to do.
You know, you… you push away,
and he's the chief… chief of the village,
translation.ko: 만약에 밀어냈다간 그 사람은 촌장이라 힘이 있었어요

translation.en: so it's like, you know, he's got the power.
A few days later, I told the head guy of the camp.
He kind of made it… He made it seem as if I was blowing things out of proportion.
translation.ko: 그 사람은 제가 과장하는 것처럼 몰아갔죠

translation.en: And how could I accuse Tui of such acts?
translation.ko: 그런데 제가 어떻게 촌장을 고발할 수 있었겠어요?

translation.en: So much so that he left me there for longer.
translation.ko: 심지어 날 그 집에 더 오래 있게 했어요

translation.en: [Chris] Obviously, the last thing that Pacific Coast Academy wanted
was to have a videotape like this taken
outside of their possession,
'cause they knew how damning it was.
And so the parent who made the videotape
translation.ko: 그래서 이 영상을 제작한 아이 아버지는

translation.en: contacted the US Embassy,
and he told them he needed to get out of the country with his son
translation.ko: 퍼시픽 코스트 아카데미가 이 사실을 알아내기 전에

translation.en: before the, um, staff at PCA knew what had happened.
And the embassy realized this is bad stuff. This is criminal.
[Chris] So he headed immediately to the airport,
and with them was a staff member from the US Embassy
who had the videotape hidden in a briefcase.
translation.ko: 그 직원의 서류 가방에 비디오테이프를 숨겼어요

translation.en: The Pacific Coast Academy had contacted the Samoan authorities at the airport,
translation.ko: 퍼시픽 코스트 아카데미는 공항의 사모아 당국에 연락해

translation.en: saying, "Don't let him leave with this videotape."
translation.ko: 그 사람이 비디오테이프를 갖고 출국하게 해선 안 된다고 했어요

translation.en: They knew it would not only hurt their business,
translation.ko: 사모아 당국에 이렇게 말했죠 그 영상이 유출되면

translation.en: but they told the Samoan authorities
translation.ko: 자기들 사업만 타격을 입는 게 아니라

translation.en: if this videotape got out, it would hurt tourism.
[Chris] The Samoan authorities questioned the father
and asked him and asked him and asked him where the tape was.
translation.ko: 테이프가 어디에 있는지 묻고 또 물었죠

translation.en: And he said, "I already mailed it to the United States."
So he gets through security.
He gets the tape from the US Embassy official, and he makes it out of Samoa.
translation.ko: 미 대사관 직원에게 테이프를 받아 사모아를 빠져나왔어요

translation.en: [Catie] That's when the news cameras came, and it kind of got outta hand.
translation.ko: 뉴스 카메라가 들이닥쳤고 상황은 걷잡을 수 없었어요

translation.en: I remember there being a news helicopter circling around our house in California.
translation.ko: 뉴스 헬리콥터가 캘리포니아의 우리 집 위를 뱅뱅 돈 게 생각나요

translation.en: Like, right above.
It was just constant.
His name is attached to something that he wasn't even a… Like…
translation.ko: "학대" "카티사노" 거기에 아빠 이름이 올랐죠 아빠는 그 일에…

translation.en: Just pisses me off. Honestly.
Like, he was barely there. I mean, he was basically out at that point.
translation.ko: 아빠는 거기에 계시지도 않았죠 그 일과는 아무 상관 없었어요

translation.en: That's when, I guess, they went in and got the kids out.
translation.ko: 아마 그때 사람들이 가서 아이들을 데리고 나왔을 거예요

translation.en: [woman] I was working at the US Embassy in New Zealand at the time,
translation.ko: 당시 저는 뉴질랜드 주재 미국 대사관에서 일하고 있었는데

translation.en: where officials had advised me
that they had this, um, problem out at the camp,
translation.ko: 공무원들이 캠프에 문제가 생겼으니 "메리루 - 전 미국 대사관 직원"

translation.en: and we need to go and find out what is going on.
translation.ko: 가서 무슨 일인지 확인해 보는 게 좋겠다고 했어요

translation.en: [Mary-Lou] These kids couldn't be left in that situation.
translation.ko: 아이들은 말도 안 되는 환경에 방치돼 있었죠

translation.en: [Mary-Lou] We managed to gain entry to the camp.
It was very sparse.
It was basically just us there,
and all the children had been removed.
There was obviously something going on.
We walked around the perimeter, and then we heard this noise.
translation.ko: 우린 주변을 돌아다녔고 어떤 소리를 들었어요

translation.en: We went down, and we found one of the children there.
translation.ko: 소리를 따라가 보니 한 아이가 있었죠

translation.en: He was quite sick,
and he was very reluctant initially,
um, probably for fear of retribution, to say anything to us.
translation.ko: 나중에 벌 받을 게 두려워서 아무 말 안 한 것 같아요

translation.en: But then, finally, he told us
that they had all been deliberately moved off the camp.
translation.ko: 하지만 결국 입을 열었죠 캠프 관계자들이 아이들을 캠프 밖으로 옮겼다고요

translation.en: But we didn't know where. We had no idea where they could have gone.
translation.ko: 하지만 그 장소는 몰랐죠 어디로 갔는지는 알 수 없었어요

translation.en: [Amber] It was most definitely a really weird day from the very beginning.
Uh, they were nice to us.
Nicer than… You know, it was strange.
They sent us to a beach.
[Mary-Lou] I do remember just going through the middle of the jungle,
still not really knowing what we were going to find when we got there.
translation.ko: 그때까지도 그곳에 도착해서 뭘 발견하게 될지 전혀 몰랐죠

translation.en: Thinking, "How did they get these kids through here?"
[Amber] We were only supposed to be there for a short period of time.
And then, all of a sudden…
black SUVs with blacked-out windows,
one after the other, just came…
barreling through where we were.
I don't know where they came from.
I just remember they were there barreling through.
translation.ko: 그냥 미친 듯이 달려온 것만 기억나요

translation.en: [Mary-Lou] The children were down on the beach.
I remember just looking at them and thinking, "Oh my goodness."
[Amber] And somebody popped… popped out of the van…
and said that they were with the American Embassy.
It had to be fake.
There's no way that somebody cared enough.
translation.ko: 누가 우리를 신경 쓸 리 없잖아요

translation.en: Especially about me. That's… There's no way.
translation.ko: 특히 저는요 말도 안 되는 일이었어요

translation.en: [Chris] This videotape became the basis for legal action.
[Chris] A grand jury took testimony from the kids who were in Pacific Coast Academy and the parents.
translation.ko: 대배심은 PCA에 있었던 아이들과 부모의 증언을 들었죠

translation.en: And what's fascinating is the guy who got the videotape out,
translation.ko: 흥미로웠던 건 그 테이프를 가져온 아버지께 사람들이 물었어요

translation.en: they ask him, "How could you be so stupid to send your kid to a program like this?"
translation.ko: 그 테이프를 가져온 아버지께 사람들이 물었어요 '어떻게 아들을 그런 데 보내는 멍청한 짓을 할 수 있죠?'

translation.en: And he pulls out the Pacific Coast Academy brochure that Steve wrote,
translation.ko: 그러자 그는 스티브가 쓴 PCA 안내 책자를 꺼내서

translation.en: and he reads what kind of a kid Pacific Coast Academy is created for.
translation.ko: 퍼시픽 코스트 아카데미가 어떤 아이들을 위해 만들어졌는지 읽었어요

translation.en: And he sets it down, and he says,
"They just described my son. That's why I chose it."
translation.ko: '이게 딱 제 아들이에요 그래서 여기를 골랐죠'

translation.en: Cartisano knew the emotional touchpoints
for parents in crisis who literally felt, "I don't have a choice."
translation.ko: 절박한 부모들의 감정을 건드리는 정확한 지점을 알았어요

translation.en: But Steve was never really held accountable
translation.ko: 하지만 스티브는 제대로 된 책임을 지지 않았죠 "퍼시픽 코스트 아카데미"

translation.en: because the world switched,
9/11 happened, priorities went elsewhere.
And Steve Cartisano, despite everything he did,
translation.ko: 스티브 카티사노는 정말 끔찍한 일을 저질렀지만

translation.en: he was not really a national security threat.
Shortly after Dave got back from Samoa,
translation.ko: 데이브가 사모아에서 돌아오고 얼마 안 돼서

translation.en: that's when I kind of started to get out of control.
I mean, I was becoming a wild teenager at that point.
translation.ko: 그때 전 거친 십 대가 돼 가고 있었죠

translation.en: I started hanging out with my brother's friends,
and then they started using pretty shortly after, and I followed suit.
translation.ko: 그 친구들은 얼마 지나지 않아 약을 하기 시작했고 저도 따라서 했죠

translation.en: I would literally come home from work, and my TV would be gone,
translation.ko: 퇴근하고 집에 오면 TV가 없고, VCR이 없고

translation.en: and my VCR would be gone,
and the snowblower would be missing out of the garage,
translation.ko: TV가 없고, VCR이 없고 차고에서 제설기가 없어져 있었죠

translation.en: because they were stealing,
and, um, you know, they would take things from the house
translation.ko: 애들이 훔쳐 가서요 집에 있는 물건을 팔아서 약값을 댄 거죠

translation.en: and hock it to pay for their drugs.
translation.ko: 집에 있는 물건을 팔아서 약값을 댄 거죠

translation.en: And so now I had two children heavily using heroin.
translation.ko: 이젠 헤로인에 중독된 아이가 둘이 됐어요

translation.en: We're talking about kids in a crack house, or they're running away, out of control.
translation.ko: 지금 우리가 말하는 아이들은 마약과 가출을 일삼고 통제 불능이죠

translation.en: And when they're 25, all the excuses of why they quit high school
translation.ko: 이 아이들이 25살이 되면 왜 고등학교를 중퇴했고

translation.en: or why they were doing drugs aren't gonna matter.
translation.ko: 왜 마약에 손대게 됐는지 그 어떤 변명도 통하지 않아요

translation.en: I overdosed in Seattle multiple times.
translation.ko: 시애틀에서 여러 번 과다 복용을 했어요

translation.en: And then I got in a really bad car accident and got arrested.
translation.ko: 그러다 아주 큰 교통사고를 내서 체포됐죠

translation.en: We bailed David out of jail a couple of times
and learned the hard way that that was a bad idea.
translation.ko: 그게 잘못된 선택이었다는 걸 뼈저리게 배웠죠

translation.en: So, eventually, when Catie got arrested, we left her in jail.
translation.ko: 그래서 케이티가 체포됐을 땐 그냥 구치소에 뒀어요

translation.en: Kids need to learn this lesson. They are responsible for their own lives and accountable for their own actions.
translation.ko: 아이들은 자신의 삶과 행동에 책임이 있다는 걸 배워야 합니다

translation.en: I was so mad.
We both felt guilt. We… We… You always question.
translation.ko: 우리 둘 다 죄책감을 느껴요 우리는 늘 의문을 품죠

translation.en: "Should I have done something differently? Could I have done something differently?"
translation.ko: '내가 다르게 했어야 하나? 다르게 할 수 있었나?'

translation.en: I realized what my life was gonna be if I didn't do anything different,
translation.ko: 달라지지 않으면 제 인생이 어떻게 될지 보였죠

translation.en: so I just got, uh, heavily involved in the recovery community,
translation.ko: 그래서 회복 공동체에 정말 많이 참여했고

translation.en: and then, here we are 13 years later.
translation.ko: 그래서 회복 공동체에 정말 많이 참여했고 13년 뒤에 여기 있네요

translation.en: On the fourth week, they go on a four-day solo period.
translation.ko: 넷째 주에는 나흘간 솔로 기간을 가져요

translation.en: So all the drugs are out of their system.
They wanna go home and be sons and daughters to their parents again
translation.ko: 아이들은 집으로 돌아가 다시 부모님의 아들딸로 살며

translation.en: and get an education.
[Debbie] David has continued to struggle.
[interviewer] Where is David now?
He's in prison, and, uh, he'll be there for about three more years.
translation.ko: 교도소에 있어요 3년 정도 더 있을 거예요

translation.en: [Debbie] Can you turn around, face the wall? Over here. Come back.
[Catie] Yeah. And that's Dad and Dave.
It was hard. Right when I got out of rehab is when my dad got diagnosed with cancer.
translation.ko: 힘들었어요 제가 재활 센터에서 나오자마자 아빠가 암 진단을 받으셨죠

translation.en: Cancer that had progressed to grade four, I believe it was. Colon cancer.
He battled it for six or seven years.
Eventually was still fighting it and died of a heart attack,
translation.ko: 그렇게 계속 싸우던 와중에 심장 마비로 죽었어요

translation.en: is what they told us.
And that was, I think, three years ago now.
[Horsehair] I don't think Steve was a bad guy.
Um, I think he lost his way for a period of time, um, is how I see it.
translation.ko: 제가 보기에는 한동안 길을 잃었던 것 같아요

translation.en: I don't think he was a bad human being at his core.
Um, he was probably a good person to his core.
The part of the story that has always got under my skin is,
even though we got him acquitted, he stiffed me.
translation.ko: 우리가 무죄 판결을 받아냈는데도 돈을 떼먹었다는 거예요

translation.en: Never paid me the balance, and that just pissed me off.
translation.ko: 잔금을 주지 않았고 그게 너무 화가 났죠

translation.en: I never heard from him again. In fact, until I heard from your production company,
translation.ko: 그 뒤로 소식을 못 들었어요 제작진에게 연락을 받기까지는

translation.en: I didn't even know what happened to him.
I liked Steve.
Uh, uh… I really did until I realized…
translation.ko: 스티브가 한 모든 일을 알기 전까지는

translation.en: everything that he'd been doing.
I mean, he probably took 50 grand off you.
translation.ko: 그 사람은 아버지 돈 5만 달러를 훔친 거예요

translation.en: Probably.
[Kinney] Several years ago, I put in a Google search for "Challenger Foundation."
translation.ko: 몇 년 전에 구글에 '챌린저 재단'을 검색해 봤어요

translation.en: I wanted to connect with the other people who had been on the survival trips.
translation.ko: 그 생존 여행에 참가한 다른 사람들을 찾고 싶었거든요

translation.en: That's when I saw his obituary.
It was an extreme mixture of feeling… shock and sadness…
to anger.
It was the catalyst for me finally speaking up about what had happened to me.
translation.ko: 그걸 계기로 드디어 제가 겪은 일을 말할 수 있게 됐죠

translation.en: [Kinney] The first program I went on was in Hawaii.
There's a section called Solo.
Solo was an opportunity to learn that you can survive on your own,
translation.ko: 솔로는 혼자서 생존할 수 있다는 걸 배우는 기회였죠, 내가…

translation.en: that you can, um…
You… You can get through hard things.
translation.ko: 힘든 일을 이겨낼 수 있다는 걸요

translation.en: And Steve made me what was called "the runner,"
and I had a walkie-talkie.
I was terrified,
and so Steve said, "If you need me,"
you know, "If you are scared, and you need me,
just press the talk button, and I'll come to you."
translation.ko: '무섭거나 내가 필요하면 말하기 버튼을 눌러' '그럼 바로 갈게'

translation.en: I was 13 years old and, um, alone.
And so he came, and… And he said, "Do you need anything?"
translation.ko: 스티브가 와서 필요한 게 있는지 물었죠

translation.en: And I said, "Yes, I would be so grateful if you could bring me lotion."
translation.ko: 그래서 전 로션을 갖다주면 정말 고마울 거라고 했어요

translation.en: My skin was so dry.
[voice breaking] Sorry, gotta give me a second.
And so he brought this lotion,
and he offered to put some on my back.
And I wasn't entirely comfortable,
but it wasn't so outside of the range of abnormal.
Um, he asked me to lay on my stomach,
kind of straddled me, and, um, was putting it on my back and massaging my back.
translation.ko: 제 위에 올라타서 등에 로션을 바르고 문질렀죠

translation.en: And then he asked me to flip over.
And I…
I did not want to, and I froze.
And he said, "It's not a big deal. Just… Just turn over." [sniffs]
And he…
began to put lotion on my shoulders and my chest.
translation.ko: 제 어깨와 그 주변에 로션을 바르기 시작했어요

translation.en: And, um… And then he moved his hands down…
to my breasts, and I tried to push his hands away. [sniffs]
translation.ko: 제 가슴으로요 전 손을 밀어내려고 했어요

translation.en: And he said, "It's not a big deal. Just think of me like your father."
And all I could think was, "My father would never touch me like this."
translation.ko: 머릿속엔 이 생각뿐이었어요 '우리 아빠는 날 이렇게 안 만져'

translation.en: It's funny. It dawned on me recently…
as I looked back…
Actually, I was talking with a friend,
and I realized that all the things
translation.ko: 친구랑 얘기하다 깨달았는데 전 스티브를 정말 좋은 사람이라고만 생각했어요

translation.en: that I thought were so lovely and so nice about Steve,
translation.ko: 전 스티브를 정말 좋은 사람이라고만 생각했어요

translation.en: it was just that he was grooming me.
I didn't know it at the time. I didn't even… It didn't even dawn on me until recently. [sniffs]
Couple of years after, I told my mother.
Not in detail, for sure.
But I did tell her that he had touched me and that he had, uh, been sexual with me.
translation.ko: 그 사람이 날 만졌고 성관계를 했다고 말했어요

translation.en: [interviewer] And did she do anything? Did she report it?
No.
The reason why she didn't was she thought that…
That he was doing something good for the kids.
translation.ko: 스티브가 아이들에게 좋은 일을 한다고 생각하셨거든요

translation.en: And that she didn't want to, in her own words, "upset the apple cart."
translation.ko: 엄마가 한 말을 그대로 하면 '초 치기 싫다'였어요

translation.en: It struck me how often he used the word "manipulative."
translation.ko: 그 사람이 '조종한다'는 말을 자주 쓴 게 떠올랐어요

translation.en: [Steve] These kids come in with all sorts of little ways of trying to manipulate.
translation.ko: 아시다시피 이 아이들은 온갖 방법으로 조종하려 하죠

translation.en: Or how often he described the children as master manipulators.
translation.ko: 아이들이 조종의 달인이라는 말을 입에 달고 살았어요

translation.en: They are master manipulators. Blaming everybody else for their problems.
translation.ko: 이 아이들은 조종의 달인이에요 자기 문제를 남 탓으로 돌리죠

translation.en: And as an adult watching that,
realizing that he was the most masterful manipulator of them all.
translation.ko: 어른이 돼서 보니까 알겠더라고요 스티브야말로 우리 중에서 가장 뛰어난 조종의 달인이었어요

translation.en: [reporter] That's certainly a convenient out, isn't it?
Being able to attack the credibility of the kids, knowing that they're troubled kids to begin with.
translation.ko: 애초에 문제아들이었으니 거짓말로 치부할 수 있잖아요

translation.en: Well, it's not an out. It's… It's the facts.
[Chris] This is still a thriving industry. There's lots of copycats now running.
translation.ko: "야생 치료 캠프는 지금도 운영되고 있다" 여전히 잘나가는 산업이에요 모방 업체가 많죠

translation.en: When I was 16, my parents sent me to a wilderness therapy program
translation.ko: 16살 때 부모님이 저를 야생 치료 프로그램에 보냈어요

translation.en: very similar to the one that Paris Hilton went to, and let me tell you how that went.
translation.ko: 패리스 힐튼이 간 것과 비슷했죠 어땠는지 얘기해 줄게요

translation.en: Steve Cartisano marketed trauma as a means to a cure.
translation.ko: 스티브 카티사노는 트라우마를 치료 수단으로 내세웠어요

translation.en: So the copycats then turn this into a huge industry.
translation.ko: 모방 업체들은 이걸 거대 산업으로 바꿨죠

translation.en: And at night, they would take my shoes and wrap me up in a tarp
translation.ko: 밤에는 제 신발을 뺏고 절 방수포로 싸서

translation.en: and lay on the end to restrict me from moving.
translation.ko: 가장자리에 눕혀 꼼짝도 못 하게 했어요

translation.en: There's many people, I think, who will today feel like, "It did change my life,
translation.ko: 그게 삶을 변화시켰다고 느끼는 사람도 많겠지만

translation.en: but maybe not for the best."
It has definitely made me who I am today. Well, it's played a big role.
translation.ko: 그게 확실히 지금의 절 만들었어요 큰 역할을 했죠

translation.en: I was the drug addict pushing the shopping cart down the street, homeless.
translation.ko: 전 마약 중독자였어요 카트를 밀고 다니는 노숙자였죠

translation.en: And I survived only because
I knew how to live with very little to nothing.
translation.ko: 거의 아무것도 없이 사는 법을 알았기 때문이죠

translation.en: I've spent most of my life… just trying to survive,
translation.ko: 전 거의 평생을 살아남으려 발버둥 치며 보냈어요

translation.en: and then I put myself in situations where I have to survive,
translation.ko: 살아남아야만 하는 상황에 자꾸 절 몰아넣죠

translation.en: you know, because that's what I know. That's where I'm comfortable.
